meeting_annotations.speaker: Marcel Schreier
meeting_annotations.transcript: So essentially the the the it's about materials. So this is for Jianbing, right? So the you need to design a molecule like very specifically that that can under all of these conditions kind of have exactly this thermodynamic um energy difference, right?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jianbing 'Jimmy' Jiang
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, in term in terms of tunability, the molecular structures are really advantages. So there are a lot of sites that you can play around. But there are there are definitely some disadvantages of these systems like like the stability issues, etc. Okay, so because, you know, for for molecular systems, uh the the the atoms are linked not always by very strong bonds, but sometimes very labile bonds have to be used. So under pretty harsh conditions, especially when there is a heat, where when when there is um quite high or low potentials applied, these bonds might tend to break causing stability issue. Yeah. So there's there's always a trade trade off for for for a system.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alissa Park
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think there are a lot of discussions on mass transfer limitation as well, which is inevitable since such a low concentration. And like instead, it's almost like extraction, right? So you need to mix this air quite a bit, not only finding reducing power. So we have to design even materials how to increase the feature area, all those things. Much more challenging, but interesting at the same time.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Chris Jones
meeting_annotations.transcript: One of the things we haven't talked about yet that I'll throw out there in case you're interested is um if you imagine a future where we are going to have to pipeline CO2 because we're doing CO2 capture from point sources, um industry, air, etc. There's certain specifications that are required for purity of the gases to go into pipeline. And actually the the the one of the more difficult ones to meet is an oxygen purity. So probably the least discussed but still important separation related to DAC is because you're capturing from such an oxygen rich stream that even if you have very good selectivity to CO2 and you minimize the amount of energy to do the separation and everything looks good, you tend to capture a not insubstantial amount of oxygen as well and quite often you can't hit the pipeline specs for oxygen. So for those of you who design absorbent materials, um CO2 water is a really important selectivity and then CO2 oxygen is probably the next most important one, but it's one that so far not many people talk about.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Betar Gallant
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um what is the material origin of the intolerance to oxygen? Is it like a corrosive process or something else?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Chris Jones
meeting_annotations.transcript: So the one that Alissa referred to was I believe she's referring to amines and then it's uh amine oxidation to form uh amids and imines which reduce your um you know, your basicity. So that the alpha CH bond next to the amine is pretty labile and so you get a radical extraction from that and then you get an auto oxidation scheme that basically in the end chews things up and spits out CO2 and ammonia.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alissa Park
meeting_annotations.transcript: This is typical even for um point source capture systems, the degradation of amine. It happens.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Chris Jones
meeting_annotations.transcript: And sometimes yeah, in liquid point source systems, especially aqueous systems, sometimes that oxidation is much faster because you're leaching catalytic transition metals from your process equipment into that liquid aqueous amine phase.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Chris Jones
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um but you but you have the added advantage in a liquid that you can have a purge stream and an uh a slow addition of uh makeup amine which is harder to manage in a non non moving bed solid application.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Betar Gallant
